comment_text.mn117:1.1: This is one of the two major treatments of the noble eightfold path in the Middle Discourses, the other being MN 141, where each factor is defined in detail. This discourse emphasizes the interrelationships between the factors, especially as they support right immersion. The meaning of the title is explained in the final passage.
comment_text.mn117:2.1: The first portion of this sutta is also at SN 45.28:1.2, to which the current sutta can be seen as a commentary. | “Vital condition” is upanisa; this is a condition for something that is both necessary and strongly conducive. | “Prerequiste” is parikkhāra, the “equipment” or “requirement”.
comment_text.mn117:3.4: While it is possible to obtain immersion outside the context of the noble eightfold path, without all the factors of the path working together it does not result in liberation and hence is not “right” immersion. | This became known in the Abhidhamma as lokuttara jhāna, where it is used in the same sense as the sutta: a meditative absorption which, empowered by all the path factors in concert, leads to the realization of the Dhamma. This is contrasted with the lokiya jhāna that leads only to rebirth in the Brahmā realm; see comment on MN 7:19.6. Later, the commentarial tradition analyzed it further as a series of mind moments that occur at the occasion of realization.
comment_text.mn117:4.1: In the Gradual Training, it is hearing the Dhamma that sets you on the path (MN 101:31.1).
comment_text.mn117:4.3: It is not just learning by rote, but the ability to make critical distinctions.
comment_text.mn117:6.3: This unique phrase refers to the kind of right view that results in a good rebirth but not liberation. This kind of right view is not specifically Buddhist. Compare sāsavaṁ upādāniyaṁ (the five grasping aggregates “accompanied by defilements and prone to being grasped”, SN 22.48:2.2) and iddhi sāsavā saupadhikā, ‘no ariyā’ti (“psychic powers that are accompanied by defilements and attachments, and are said to be ignoble”, DN 28:18.3). | For “partakes of good deeds” (puññabhāgiyā), see AN 6.63, where it refers to a rebirth that results from “defilement”.
comment_text.mn117:6.4: This is the right view of one on the noble path. The suttas do not elsewhere distinguish these two kinds of path factors, and the “transcendent” analysis is not found in the parallels in Chinese (MA 189 at T i 735b) or Tibetan (Up 6.080 at D 4094 mngon pa, nyu 43b7). A similar distinction, however, is made in the Chinese translation of the Saṁyukta Āgama of the (Mūla)-Sarvāstivāda at SA 785 and SA 789, which contains analyses of the transcendent factors that are similar to those in Pali. | “Transcendent” (lokuttara) means “leading beyond the world (of transmigration)”. Elsewhere in early texts it is used of discourses (SN 20.7:1.6, SN 55.53:2.2, AN 2.47:1.5, AN 5.79:5.2; see too MN 96:12.12), and of certain reflective realizations of a noble one (MN 48:14.7, MN 122:18.1).
comment_text.mn117:8.2: Whereas elsewhere right view is explained in terms of what you understand (the four noble truths MN 141:24.1), this analysis shifts focus to how you understand: wisdom functions in the context of the path as a whole. Later texts expand on this (eg. Mnd 2:82.4, Ne 17:17.3, Ds 2.1.1:28.2). | As to the phrase “intent on the noble, intent on the undefiled”, the expressions ariyacitta and anāsavacitta are unique. It is tempting to translate anāsavacitta as “undefiled mind”, but that would pertain only to the arahant who has completed the path, whereas this is talking about one still in the process of developing the path. Here citta must mean “intention” (eg. MN 120:3.4; cf. the later term bodhicitta). Commentary is silent.
comment_text.mn117:9.3: The path is linear in that each factor depends on the previous (MN 117:34.3, see too eg. SN 45.1). But it is not just linear, as the factors are always interacting. Right view understands what to do; right effort does the work; and right mindfulness monitors and checks.
comment_text.mn117:10.1: Right view is the anterior condition for all the path factors.
comment_text.mn117:10.3: See MN 19 for how the bodhisatta developed this practice.
comment_text.mn117:14.2: This passage shows that the scope of saṅkappa or vitakka is wider than discursive “thought”, especially in deep meditation. This definition is similar to that in the Abhidhamma (eg. Vb 3:23.2) | Takka (“thinking”) is normally “logic” but here is a synonym of vitakka. | Appanā (“planting”) is where a movement enters its goal, as a river the ocean (SN 15.8:2.3), or a peg the wood (Mil 3.3.13, for which see also MN 20.3.4). | Byappanā is an intensive form that appears only in this definition. | Abhiniropana is likewise a unique term, with the sense of “sinking into” or “embedding”. Compare Sanskrit āropaṇa, “placing or fixing in or upon”. | For “verbal process” see MN 44:15.3 = SN 41.6:2.4.
comment_text.mn117:19.2: Right speech is defined solely as abstinence here, whereas elsewhere it also includes actually speaking in a constructive way (eg. MN 114:6.18). The negative mode of definition is more technically precise, as it includes times when one is silent or in deep meditation.
comment_text.mn117:20.2: This sequence of synonyms (ārati virati paṭivirati veramaṇī) is otherwise found only in late canonical texts (eg. Cnd 6:11.6, Vb 4:61.2, Pvr 4:5.2).
comment_text.mn117:29.2: This applies to everyone, but especially to monastics, in reference to unwholesome ways of seeking requisites and material profits. For laypeople, five kinds of wrong livelihood are specified: trade in weapons, living creatures, meat, intoxicants, and poison (AN 5.177:1.3).
comment_text.mn117:31.2: Defined for a monastic in the long section on ethics in the Sāmaññaphalasutta (DN 2:56.1) and for a lay person as trade in weapons, living creatures, meat, intoxicants, and poisons (AN 5.177:1.3).
comment_text.mn117:33.3: This, the fifth factor of the path, is the last factor described as encompassed by right view, effort, and mindfulness. I think a purpose of this discourse is to make it clear that they also apply to the first five factors, the final three being taken as self-evident.
comment_text.mn117:34.3: This extends the linear arising to two additional factors: right knowledge and right freedom (see also DN 18:27.8, AN 10.103:2.3). These are not divided into two kinds, as they apply solely to the perfected ones.
comment_text.mn117:34.4: Right knowledge is the wisdom perfected by the ending of defilements, while right freedom is the liberation from rebirth.
comment_text.mn117:35.3: The term nijjiṇṇa (“worn away”) is associated with the Jains (eg. MN 14:17.8, MN 101:10.8).
comment_text.mn117:36.1: The twenty are the ten factors, plus ten for the relevant qualities they promote.
comment_text.mn117:38.1: For discussion of this obscure passage, see note on SN 22.62:13.2.

root_text.mn117:1.2: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṁ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
root_text.mn117:2.1: “ariyaṁ vo, bhikkhave, sammāsamādhiṁ desessāmi saupanisaṁ saparikkhāraṁ.
root_text.mn117:2.2: Taṁ suṇātha, sādhukaṁ manasi karotha, bhāsissāmī”ti.
root_text.mn117:2.3: “Evaṁ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṁ.
root_text.mn117:3.1: “Katamo ca, bhikkhave, ariyo sammāsamādhi saupaniso saparikkhāro?
root_text.mn117:3.2: Seyyathidaṁ—sammādiṭṭhi, sammāsaṅkappo, sammāvācā, sammākammanto, sammāājīvo, sammāvāyāmo, sammāsati;
root_text.mn117:3.3: yā kho, bhikkhave, imehi sattahaṅgehi cittassa ekaggatā parikkhatā—
root_text.mn117:3.4: ayaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, ariyo sammāsamādhi saupaniso itipi, saparikkhāro itipi.
root_text.mn117:4.3: Micchādiṭṭhiṁ ‘micchādiṭṭhī’ti pajānāti, sammādiṭṭhiṁ ‘sammādiṭṭhī’ti pajānāti—sāssa hoti sammādiṭṭhi.
root_text.mn117:5.2: ‘Natthi dinnaṁ, natthi yiṭṭhaṁ, natthi hutaṁ, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko, natthi ayaṁ loko, natthi paro loko, natthi mātā, natthi pitā, natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi loke samaṇabrāhmaṇā sammaggatā sammāpaṭipannā ye imañca lokaṁ parañca lokaṁ sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedentī’ti—
root_text.mn117:6.3: atthi, bhikkhave, sammādiṭṭhi sāsavā puññabhāgiyā upadhivepakkā;
root_text.mn117:6.4: atthi, bhikkhave, sammādiṭṭhi ariyā anāsavā lokuttarā maggaṅgā.
root_text.mn117:7.1: Katamā ca, bhikkhave, sammādiṭṭhi sāsavā puññabhāgiyā upadhivepakkā?
root_text.mn117:7.2: ‘Atthi dinnaṁ, atthi yiṭṭhaṁ, atthi hutaṁ, atthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko, atthi ayaṁ loko, atthi paro loko, atthi mātā, atthi pitā, atthi sattā opapātikā, atthi loke samaṇabrāhmaṇā sammaggatā sammāpaṭipannā ye imañca lokaṁ parañca lokaṁ sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedentī’ti—
root_text.mn117:7.3: ayaṁ, bhikkhave, sammādiṭṭhi sāsavā puññabhāgiyā upadhivepakkā.
root_text.mn117:8.1: Katamā ca, bhikkhave, sammādiṭṭhi ariyā anāsavā lokuttarā maggaṅgā?
root_text.mn117:8.2: Yā kho, bhikkhave, ariyacittassa anāsavacittassa ariyamaggasamaṅgino ariyamaggaṁ bhāvayato paññā paññindriyaṁ paññābalaṁ dhammavicayasambojjhaṅgo sammādiṭṭhi maggaṅgaṁ—
root_text.mn117:8.3: ayaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, sammādiṭṭhi ariyā anāsavā lokuttarā maggaṅgā.
root_text.mn117:9.1: So micchādiṭṭhiyā pahānāya vāyamati, sammādiṭṭhiyā, upasampadāya, svāssa hoti sammāvāyāmo.
root_text.mn117:9.2: So sato micchādiṭṭhiṁ pajahati, sato sammādiṭṭhiṁ upasampajja viharati, sāssa hoti sammāsati.
root_text.mn117:9.3: Itiyime tayo dhammā sammādiṭṭhiṁ anuparidhāvanti anuparivattanti, seyyathidaṁ—sammādiṭṭhi, sammāvāyāmo, sammāsati.
root_text.mn117:10.3: Micchāsaṅkappaṁ ‘micchāsaṅkappo’ti pajānāti, sammāsaṅkappaṁ ‘sammāsaṅkappo’ti pajānāti, sāssa hoti sammādiṭṭhi.
root_text.mn117:12.3: atthi, bhikkhave, sammāsaṅkappo sāsavo puññabhāgiyo upadhivepakko;
root_text.mn117:12.4: atthi, bhikkhave, sammāsaṅkappo ariyo anāsavo lokuttaro maggaṅgo.
root_text.mn117:13.1: Katamo ca, bhikkhave, sammāsaṅkappo sāsavo puññabhāgiyo upadhivepakko?
root_text.mn117:14.1: Katamo ca, bhikkhave, sammāsaṅkappo ariyo anāsavo lokuttaro maggaṅgo?
root_text.mn117:14.2: Yo kho, bhikkhave, ariyacittassa anāsavacittassa ariyamaggasamaṅgino ariyamaggaṁ bhāvayato takko vitakko saṅkappo appanā byappanā cetaso abhiniropanā vacīsaṅkhāro—
root_text.mn117:14.3: ayaṁ, bhikkhave, sammāsaṅkappo ariyo anāsavo lokuttaro maggaṅgo.
root_text.mn117:15.1: So micchāsaṅkappassa pahānāya vāyamati, sammāsaṅkappassa upasampadāya, svāssa hoti sammāvāyāmo.
root_text.mn117:15.2: So sato micchāsaṅkappaṁ pajahati, sato sammāsaṅkappaṁ upasampajja viharati; sāssa hoti sammāsati.
root_text.mn117:15.3: Itiyime tayo dhammā sammāsaṅkappaṁ anuparidhāvanti anuparivattanti, seyyathidaṁ—sammādiṭṭhi, sammāvāyāmo, sammāsati.
root_text.mn117:16.3: Micchāvācaṁ ‘micchāvācā’ti pajānāti, sammāvācaṁ ‘sammāvācā’ti pajānāti; sāssa hoti sammādiṭṭhi.
root_text.mn117:17.2: Musāvādo, pisuṇā vācā, pharusā vācā, samphappalāpo—
root_text.mn117:18.3: atthi, bhikkhave, sammāvācā sāsavā puññabhāgiyā upadhivepakkā;
root_text.mn117:18.4: atthi, bhikkhave, sammāvācā ariyā anāsavā lokuttarā maggaṅgā.
root_text.mn117:19.1: Katamā ca, bhikkhave, sammāvācā sāsavā puññabhāgiyā upadhivepakkā?
root_text.mn117:19.2: Musāvādā veramaṇī, pisuṇāya vācāya veramaṇī, pharusāya vācāya veramaṇī, samphappalāpā veramaṇī—
root_text.mn117:19.3: ayaṁ, bhikkhave, sammāvācā sāsavā puññabhāgiyā upadhivepakkā.
root_text.mn117:20.1: Katamā ca, bhikkhave, sammāvācā ariyā anāsavā lokuttarā maggaṅgā?
root_text.mn117:20.2: Yā kho, bhikkhave, ariyacittassa anāsavacittassa ariyamaggasamaṅgino ariyamaggaṁ bhāvayato catūhi vacīduccaritehi ārati virati paṭivirati veramaṇī—
root_text.mn117:20.3: ayaṁ, bhikkhave, sammāvācā ariyā anāsavā lokuttarā maggaṅgā.
root_text.mn117:21.1: So micchāvācāya pahānāya vāyamati, sammāvācāya upasampadāya; svāssa hoti sammāvāyāmo.
root_text.mn117:21.2: So sato micchāvācaṁ pajahati, sato sammāvācaṁ upasampajja viharati; sāssa hoti sammāsati.
root_text.mn117:21.3: Itiyime tayo dhammā sammāvācaṁ anuparidhāvanti anuparivattanti, seyyathidaṁ—sammādiṭṭhi, sammāvāyāmo, sammāsati.
root_text.mn117:22.3: Micchākammantaṁ ‘micchākammanto’ti pajānāti, sammākammantaṁ ‘sammākammanto’ti pajānāti; sāssa hoti sammādiṭṭhi.
root_text.mn117:24.3: atthi, bhikkhave, sammākammanto sāsavo puññabhāgiyo upadhivepakko;
root_text.mn117:24.4: atthi, bhikkhave, sammākammanto ariyo anāsavo lokuttaro maggaṅgo.
root_text.mn117:25.1: Katamo ca, bhikkhave, sammākammanto sāsavo puññabhāgiyo upadhivepakko?
root_text.mn117:25.2: Pāṇātipātā veramaṇī, adinnādānā veramaṇī, kāmesumicchācārā veramaṇī—
root_text.mn117:25.3: ayaṁ, bhikkhave, sammākammanto sāsavo puññabhāgiyo upadhivepakko.
root_text.mn117:26.1: Katamo ca, bhikkhave, sammākammanto ariyo anāsavo lokuttaro maggaṅgo?
root_text.mn117:26.2: Yā kho, bhikkhave, ariyacittassa anāsavacittassa ariyamaggasamaṅgino ariyamaggaṁ bhāvayato tīhi kāyaduccaritehi ārati virati paṭivirati veramaṇī—
root_text.mn117:26.3: ayaṁ, bhikkhave, sammākammanto ariyo anāsavo lokuttaro maggaṅgo.
root_text.mn117:27.1: So micchākammantassa pahānāya vāyamati, sammākammantassa upasampadāya; svāssa hoti sammāvāyāmo.
root_text.mn117:27.2: So sato micchākammantaṁ pajahati, sato sammākammantaṁ upasampajja viharati; sāssa hoti sammāsati.
root_text.mn117:27.3: Itiyime tayo dhammā sammākammantaṁ anuparidhāvanti anuparivattanti, seyyathidaṁ—sammādiṭṭhi, sammāvāyāmo, sammāsati.
root_text.mn117:28.3: Micchāājīvaṁ ‘micchāājīvo’ti pajānāti, sammāājīvaṁ ‘sammāājīvo’ti pajānāti; sāssa hoti sammādiṭṭhi.
root_text.mn117:29.2: Kuhanā, lapanā, nemittikatā, nippesikatā, lābhena lābhaṁ nijigīsanatā—
root_text.mn117:30.3: atthi, bhikkhave, sammāājīvo sāsavo puññabhāgiyo upadhivepakko;
root_text.mn117:30.4: atthi, bhikkhave, sammāājīvo ariyo anāsavo lokuttaro maggaṅgo.
root_text.mn117:31.1: Katamo ca, bhikkhave, sammāājīvo sāsavo puññabhāgiyo upadhivepakko?
root_text.mn117:31.2: Idha, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako micchāājīvaṁ pahāya sammāājīvena jīvikaṁ kappeti—
root_text.mn117:31.3: ayaṁ, bhikkhave, sammāājīvo sāsavo puññabhāgiyo upadhivepakko.
root_text.mn117:32.1: Katamo ca, bhikkhave, sammāājīvo ariyo anāsavo lokuttaro maggaṅgo?
root_text.mn117:32.2: Yā kho, bhikkhave, ariyacittassa anāsavacittassa ariyamaggasamaṅgino ariyamaggaṁ bhāvayato micchāājīvā ārati virati paṭivirati veramaṇī—
root_text.mn117:32.3: ayaṁ, bhikkhave, sammāājīvo ariyo anāsavo lokuttaro maggaṅgo.
root_text.mn117:33.1: So micchāājīvassa pahānāya vāyamati, sammāājīvassa upasampadāya; svāssa hoti sammāvāyāmo.
root_text.mn117:33.2: So sato micchāājīvaṁ pajahati, sato sammāājīvaṁ upasampajja viharati; sāssa hoti sammāsati.
root_text.mn117:33.3: Itiyime tayo dhammā sammāājīvaṁ anuparidhāvanti anuparivattanti, seyyathidaṁ—sammādiṭṭhi, sammāvāyāmo, sammāsati.
root_text.mn117:34.3: Sammādiṭṭhissa, bhikkhave, sammāsaṅkappo pahoti, sammāsaṅkappassa sammāvācā pahoti, sammāvācassa sammākammanto pahoti, sammākammantassa sammāājīvo pahoti, sammāājīvassa sammāvāyāmo pahoti, sammāvāyāmassa sammāsati pahoti, sammāsatissa sammāsamādhi pahoti, sammāsamādhissa sammāñāṇaṁ pahoti, sammāñāṇassa sammāvimutti pahoti.
root_text.mn117:34.4: Iti kho, bhikkhave, aṭṭhaṅgasamannāgato sekkho, dasaṅgasamannāgato arahā hoti.
root_text.mn117:34.5: Tatrapi sammāñāṇena aneke pāpakā akusalā dhammā vigatā bhāvanāpāripūriṁ gacchanti.
root_text.mn117:35.4: Ye ca micchādiṭṭhipaccayā aneke pāpakā akusalā dhammā sambhavanti te cassa nijjiṇṇā honti.
root_text.mn117:35.5: Sammādiṭṭhipaccayā aneke kusalā dhammā bhāvanāpāripūriṁ gacchanti.
root_text.mn117:35.15: Ye ca micchāvimuttipaccayā aneke pāpakā akusalā dhammā sambhavanti te cassa nijjiṇṇā honti.
root_text.mn117:35.16: Sammāvimuttipaccayā ca aneke kusalā dhammā bhāvanāpāripūriṁ gacchanti.
root_text.mn117:36.1: Iti kho, bhikkhave, vīsati kusalapakkhā, vīsati akusalapakkhā—
root_text.mn117:36.2: mahācattārīsako dhammapariyāyo pavattito appaṭivattiyo samaṇena vā brāhmaṇena vā devena vā mārena vā brahmunā vā kenaci vā lokasmiṁ.
root_text.mn117:37.1: Yo hi koci, bhikkhave, samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā imaṁ mahācattārīsakaṁ dhammapariyāyaṁ garahitabbaṁ paṭikkositabbaṁ maññeyya tassa diṭṭheva dhamme dasasahadhammikā vādānuvādā gārayhaṁ ṭhānaṁ āgacchanti—
root_text.mn117:37.2: sammādiṭṭhiñce bhavaṁ garahati, ye ca micchādiṭṭhī samaṇabrāhmaṇā te bhoto pujjā, te bhoto pāsaṁsā;
root_text.mn117:37.3: sammāsaṅkappañce bhavaṁ garahati, ye ca micchāsaṅkappā samaṇabrāhmaṇā te bhoto pujjā, te bhoto pāsaṁsā;
root_text.mn117:37.11: sammāvimuttiñce bhavaṁ garahati, ye ca micchāvimuttī samaṇabrāhmaṇā te bhoto pujjā, te bhoto pāsaṁsā.
root_text.mn117:37.12: Yo koci, bhikkhave, samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā imaṁ mahācattārīsakaṁ dhammapariyāyaṁ garahitabbaṁ paṭikkositabbaṁ maññeyya tassa diṭṭheva dhamme ime dasasahadhammikā vādānuvādā gārayhaṁ ṭhānaṁ āgacchanti.
root_text.mn117:38.1: Yepi te, bhikkhave, ahesuṁ okkalā vassabhaññā ahetuvādā akiriyavādā natthikavādā tepi mahācattārīsakaṁ dhammapariyāyaṁ na garahitabbaṁ nappaṭikkositabbaṁ amaññiṁsu.
root_text.mn117:38.5: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandunti.

translation_text.mn117:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
translation_text.mn117:1.3: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,
translation_text.mn117:2.1: “Mendicants, I will teach you noble right immersion with its vital conditions and its prerequisites.
translation_text.mn117:2.2: Listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”
translation_text.mn117:3.1: “And what is noble right immersion with its vital conditions and its prerequisites?
translation_text.mn117:3.2: They are: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, and right mindfulness.
translation_text.mn117:3.3: Unification of mind with these seven factors as prerequisites
translation_text.mn117:3.4: is what is called noble right immersion ‘with its vital conditions’ and also ‘with its prerequisites’.
translation_text.mn117:4.1: In this context, right view comes first.
translation_text.mn117:4.2: And how does right view come first?
translation_text.mn117:4.3: When you understand wrong view as wrong view and right view as right view, that’s your right view.
translation_text.mn117:5.2: ‘There’s no meaning in giving, sacrifice, or offerings. There’s no fruit or result of good and bad deeds. There’s no afterlife. There’s no such thing as mother and father, or beings that are reborn spontaneously. And there’s no ascetic or brahmin who is rightly comported and rightly practiced, and who describes the afterlife after realizing it with their own insight.’
translation_text.mn117:6.2: Right view is twofold, I say.
translation_text.mn117:6.3: There is right view that is accompanied by defilements, partakes of good deeds, and ripens in attachments.
translation_text.mn117:6.4: And there is right view that is noble, undefiled, transcendent, a factor of the path.
translation_text.mn117:7.1: And what is right view that is accompanied by defilements, partakes of good deeds, and ripens in attachments?
translation_text.mn117:7.2: ‘There is meaning in giving, sacrifice, and offerings. There are fruits and results of good and bad deeds. There is an afterlife. There are such things as mother and father, and beings that are reborn spontaneously. And there are ascetics and brahmins who are rightly comported and rightly practiced, and who describe the afterlife after realizing it with their own insight.’
translation_text.mn117:7.3: This is right view that is accompanied by defilements, partakes of good deeds, and ripens in attachments.
translation_text.mn117:8.1: And what is right view that is noble, undefiled, transcendent, a factor of the path?
translation_text.mn117:8.2: It’s the wisdom—the faculty of wisdom, the power of wisdom, the awakening factor of investigation of principles, and right view as a factor of the path—in one intent on the noble, intent on the undefiled, who possesses the noble path and develops the noble path.
translation_text.mn117:8.3: This is called right view that is noble, undefiled, transcendent, a factor of the path.
translation_text.mn117:9.1: They make an effort to give up wrong view and embrace right view: that’s their right effort.
translation_text.mn117:9.2: Mindfully they give up wrong view and take up right view: that’s their right mindfulness.
translation_text.mn117:9.3: So these three things keep running and circling around right view, namely: right view, right effort, and right mindfulness.
translation_text.mn117:10.1: In this context, right view comes first.
translation_text.mn117:10.2: And how does right view come first?
translation_text.mn117:10.3: When you understand wrong thought as wrong thought and right thought as right thought, that’s your right view.
translation_text.mn117:11.2: Thoughts of sensuality, of malice, and of cruelty.
translation_text.mn117:12.2: Right thought is twofold, I say.

translation_text.mn117:12.4: And there is right thought that is noble, undefiled, transcendent, a factor of the path.

translation_text.mn117:13.2: Thoughts of renunciation, good will, and harmlessness.

translation_text.mn117:14.1: And what is right thought that is noble, undefiled, transcendent, a factor of the path?
translation_text.mn117:14.2: It’s the thinking—the placing of the mind, thought, planting, implanting, embedding of the mind, verbal process—in one intent on the noble, intent on the undefiled, who possesses the noble path and develops the noble path.
translation_text.mn117:14.3: This is right thought that is noble.

translation_text.mn117:15.3: So these three things keep running and circling around right thought, namely: right view, right effort, and right mindfulness.
translation_text.mn117:16.1: In this context, right view comes first.

translation_text.mn117:18.4: And there is right speech that is noble, undefiled, transcendent, a factor of the path.
translation_text.mn117:19.1: And what is right speech that is accompanied by defilements, partakes of good deeds, and ripens in attachments?
translation_text.mn117:19.2: The refraining from lying, divisive speech, harsh speech, and talking nonsense.
translation_text.mn117:19.3: This is right speech that is accompanied by defilements.
translation_text.mn117:20.1: And what is right speech that is noble, undefiled, transcendent, a factor of the path?
translation_text.mn117:20.2: It’s the desisting, abstaining, abstinence, and refraining from the four kinds of bad verbal conduct in one intent on the noble, intent on the undefiled, who possesses the noble path and develops the noble path.
translation_text.mn117:20.3: This is right speech that is noble.

translation_text.mn117:21.2: Mindfully they give up wrong speech and take up right speech: that’s their right mindfulness.
translation_text.mn117:21.3: So these three things keep running and circling around right speech, namely: right view, right effort, and right mindfulness.

translation_text.mn117:22.3: When you understand wrong action as wrong action and right action as right action, that’s your right view.

translation_text.mn117:24.4: And there is right action that is noble, undefiled, transcendent, a factor of the path.

translation_text.mn117:28.3: When you understand wrong livelihood as wrong livelihood and right livelihood as right livelihood, that’s your right view.
translation_text.mn117:29.2: Fawning, flattery, hinting, and belittling, and using material things to chase after other material things.
translation_text.mn117:30.2: Right livelihood is twofold, I say.
translation_text.mn117:30.3: There is right livelihood that is accompanied by defilements, partakes of good deeds, and ripens in attachments.
translation_text.mn117:30.4: And there is right livelihood that is noble, undefiled, transcendent, a factor of the path.
translation_text.mn117:31.1: And what is right livelihood that is accompanied by defilements, partakes of good deeds, and ripens in attachments?
translation_text.mn117:31.2: It’s when a noble disciple gives up wrong livelihood and earns a living by right livelihood.
translation_text.mn117:31.3: This is right livelihood that is accompanied by defilements.

translation_text.mn117:33.3: So these three things keep running and circling around right livelihood, namely: right view, right effort, and right mindfulness.
translation_text.mn117:34.1: In this context, right view comes first.
translation_text.mn117:34.2: And how does right view come first?
translation_text.mn117:34.3: Right view produces right thought. Right thought produces right speech. Right speech produces right action. Right action produces right livelihood. Right livelihood produces right effort. Right effort produces right mindfulness. Right mindfulness produces right immersion. Right immersion produces right knowledge. Right knowledge produces right freedom.
translation_text.mn117:34.4: So the trainee has eight factors, while the perfected one has ten factors.
translation_text.mn117:34.5: And here too, the eradication of many bad, unskillful qualities is fully developed due to right knowledge.
translation_text.mn117:35.1: In this context, right view comes first.
translation_text.mn117:35.2: And how does right view come first?
translation_text.mn117:35.3: For one of right view, wrong view is worn away.
translation_text.mn117:35.4: And the many bad, unskillful qualities that arise because of wrong view are worn away.
translation_text.mn117:35.5: And because of right view, many skillful qualities are fully developed.
translation_text.mn117:35.6: For one of right thought, wrong thought is worn away. …
translation_text.mn117:35.7: For one of right speech, wrong speech is worn away. …
translation_text.mn117:35.8: For one of right action, wrong action is worn away. …
translation_text.mn117:35.9: For one of right livelihood, wrong livelihood is worn away. …
translation_text.mn117:35.10: For one of right effort, wrong effort is worn away. …
translation_text.mn117:35.11: For one of right mindfulness, wrong mindfulness is worn away. …
translation_text.mn117:35.12: For one of right immersion, wrong immersion is worn away. …
translation_text.mn117:35.13: For one of right knowledge, wrong knowledge is worn away. …
translation_text.mn117:35.14: For one of right freedom, wrong freedom is worn away.
translation_text.mn117:35.15: And the many bad, unskillful qualities that arise because of wrong freedom are worn away.
translation_text.mn117:35.16: And because of right freedom, many skillful qualities are fully developed.
translation_text.mn117:36.1: So there are twenty on the side of the skillful, and twenty on the side of the unskillful.
translation_text.mn117:36.2: This exposition of the teaching on the Great Forty has been rolled forth. And it cannot be rolled back by any ascetic or brahmin or god or Māra or divinity or by anyone in the world.
translation_text.mn117:37.1: If any ascetic or brahmin imagines they can criticize and reject the exposition of the teaching on the Great Forty, they deserve rebuttal and criticism on ten legitimate grounds in this very life.
translation_text.mn117:37.2: If such a gentleman criticizes right view, they praise and honor the ascetics and brahmins who have wrong view.
translation_text.mn117:37.11: right freedom, they praise and honor the ascetics and brahmins who have wrong freedom.
translation_text.mn117:37.12: If any ascetic or brahmin imagines they can criticize and reject the exposition of the teaching on the Great Forty, they deserve rebuttal and criticism on these ten legitimate grounds in this very life.
translation_text.mn117:38.1: Even those those who were loud and bold advocates of the doctrines of no-cause, inaction, and nihilism, didn’t imagine that the Great Forty should be criticized or rejected.
translation_text.mn117:38.3: For fear of being blamed, provoked, and faulted.”
translation_text.mn117:38.4: That is what the Buddha said.
translation_text.mn117:38.5: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.
